author: By Alexandra Stevenson, Amy Chang Chien and Cao Li
title: China’s Celebrity Culture Is Raucous. The Authorities Want to Change That.
description: The Communist Party has declared war on idol worship, part of a broader crackdown on what it sees as toxic celebrity culture that is poisoning the minds of the country’s youth.
content: China’s online censors have for years relentlessly silenced political dissidents, #MeToo activists, liberal intellectuals, satirists and anybody else who has threatened to disturb the digital peace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Rose
title: Very Personal Computing: In Artist’s New Work, A.I. Meets Fatherhood
description: Ian Cheng brings his latest piece to the Shed, a narrative animation powered by a video game engine and partly inspired by his daughter.
content: Ian Cheng was feeling adrift. It was the start of 2013; he was nearly 30, with an art degree from Berkeley and another from Columbia, but he needed an idea, something to build a career on. Pondering the question one wintry afternoon in the balcony cafe at the Whole Foods Market on Houston Street, a place that promises people-watching and “you time,” he found himself gazing absently at the shoppers below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Isabelia Herrera and Giovanni Russonello
title: John Coltrane’s Unearthed Live ‘A Love Supreme,’ and 12 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by SZA, Fantastic Negrito, Mary Lattimore and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Kabul, Evictions, ‘Candyman’: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

author: By Alix Wall
title: A Hologram Delivered the Toast
description: It was a fitting wedding for Brittany Smith and Jeffrey Gallant, whose relationship relied on LinkedIn (“the ultimate platform for finding love”) and other technology.
content: After meeting at a Toronto bar, the Ballroom, in 2013, Jeffrey Gallant sensed he’d end up with Brittany Smith. But it couldn’t happen right away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Hanage and K.J. Seung
title: Why Provincetown’s Response to Its Covid Outbreak Was So Effective
description: The public health department’s approach to contact tracing shows a better way to monitor the disease.
content: A fourth surge of Covid-19 is filling hospitals around the United States, fueled by the relaxing of mitigation measures, the more transmissible Delta variant and lagging vaccination rates. In states and counties where Delta is surging, contact tracers are overwhelmed. But monitoring the spread of the virus remains vital to getting it under control. The public health response to a Covid-19 outbreak in Provincetown, Mass., in July offers an object lesson in how Delta changes the playing field and what’s needed to manage the pandemic’s next phase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Catch up on “The Other Two.” Don’t cook.
content: This is a preview of the At Home and Away newsletter, which is now reserved for Times subscribers. Sign up to get it in your inbox twice a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Parole Board Recommends Release of Sirhan Sirhan, Robert F. Kennedy’s Assassin
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom, who is campaigning to win a recall election in California, can choose to uphold or reject the recommendation, which would free Mr. Sirhan after more than five decades.
content: California parole commissioners recommended on Friday that Sirhan B. Sirhan should be freed on parole after spending more than 50 years in prison for assassinating Robert F. Kennedy during his campaign for president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Precious Fondren
title: Hochul Officially Announces Brian Benjamin as Lieutenant Governor
description: After promising to be more transparent than her predecessor, Gov. Kathy C. Hochul also announced an updated coronavirus death toll for the state.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: A ‘Hippie Hindu’ Wedding for a Cosmic Match
description: A family- owned micro-resort in Carmel, Calif., was the setting for Angela Braren and Gauri Manglik’s blended celebration complete with rainbow veggie tacos.
content: On a Friday morning in October 2018, Angela Braren and Gauri Manglik were riding San Francisco’s Muni to work together when Ms. Braren said she was struck with an urgency to propose to Ms. Manglik — her girlfriend of over four years — on that very day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daphne Merkin
title: David Grossman’s New Novel Is a Multigenerational Saga of Love and Loss
description: At the center of the celebrated Israeli novelist’s new book, “More Than I Love My Life,” is the story of a woman imprisoned on a Yugoslavian island for almost three years.
content: MORE THAN I LOVE MY LIFEBy David GrossmanTranslated by Jessica Cohen
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Justice Breyer on Retirement and the Role of Politics at the Supreme Court
description: In an interview prompted by his new book, the 83-year-old leader of the court’s liberal wing said he is working on a decision about when to step down.
content: WASHINGTON — Justice Stephen G. Breyer says he is struggling to decide when to retire from the Supreme Court and is taking account of a host of factors, including who will name his successor. “There are many things that go into a retirement decision,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: A baby born on an evacuation flight is named Reach, after the aircraft’s call sign.
description: A U.S. military commander said the baby was one of three born to women who have boarded evacuation flights out of Afghanistan.
content: The Afghan parents of a baby born on a C-17 aircraft evacuating passengers to Germany named their daughter after the aircraft’s call sign, a senior U.S. general said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: I Can’t Stop Wondering What’s Going On Inside My Cat’s Head
description: How my new pets got me to consider life’s deepest mysteries.
content: Some people keep pets for the cuddles and companionship; it turns out what I enjoy are the philosophical rabbit holes, the sudden tumbles into life’s deepest, most intractable mysteries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: The Guerrilla Street Artist Stumping for Larry Elder
description: The conservative provocateur Sabo says that Elder, the Republican front-runner and talk radio host, is “a good man.”
content: Every now and again over the past couple of decades, the right-wing street artist Sabo has popped up, aggravating Los Angeles liberals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Fossils Seized in Police Raid Demystify a Prehistoric Flying Reptile
description: Among the 3,000 fossils seized at a Brazilian port in 2013 was an almost complete skeleton from the pterosaur species Tupandactylus navigans, preserved in six limestone slabs.
content: Limestone slabs recovered in a 2013 police raid in Brazil have revealed the most complete fossil of a species of pterosaur ever found, providing new details about how the flying reptile might have looked and behaved some 110 million years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘He’s All That’ Review: Much Ado About Nothing
description: This gender-flipped reboot of “She’s All That” lazily rehashes the original but without its endearing weirdness.
content: Set in the late-90s heyday of MTV, “She’s All That” featured a jock who, after being dumped by his girlfriend, accepts a bet to turn a geek into a prom queen. His prize? Saving face. In “He’s All That,” the new gender-flipped Netflix remake, the stakes have shifted. For the teen beauty influencer Padgett (TikTok superstar Addison Rae), popularity pays the bills. When she’s humiliated by her jerk boyfriend on a livestream, she decides to transform the brooding Cameron (Tanner Buchanan) into a prom king in a bid to win back her followers and brand endorsements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: How Josh Ritter, Musician and Novelist, Spends His Sundays
description: In the morning he writes prose, and in the evening, songs. In between are treasure hunts and ‘power cleans’ with his family.
content: Josh Ritter is a prolific songwriter. And he’s no slouch as a novelist, either. His second book, “The Great Glorious Goddamn of It All,” told from the perspective of a 99-year-old man who is among the last of the lumberjacks in an Idaho timber town, comes out Sept. 7. His book tour will kick off the same day with a reading at Word Bookstore in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and on Oct. 8, he is scheduled to perform his music at St. Ann & the Holy Trinity Church in Brooklyn Heights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthieu Aikins and Victor J. Blue For The New York Times
title: After Airport Bombing, an Afghan Family Buries a Father, and Hope
description: The former police officer, from the Hazara ethnic minority, had hoped to help his family escape the Taliban. Instead, he is now numbered among the scores killed at the Kabul airport.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — In a shed beside the mosque his father had helped to build, Hussein’s body lay on a marble slab on Friday morning as his brother Hamid and other relatives washed him for burial. Delicately, they patched the shrapnel wounds that had killed him the day before, using bits of cotton and plaster, and clear plastic tape.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Black Reporter Proved Right By History and a Fatal Tesla Crash: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: The Foreign Policy Conversation Washington Doesn’t Want to Have
description: What America needs to learn from its Afghanistan debacle.
content: Everything about the Afghanistan withdrawal is tragic. But that tragedy is the result not of the withdrawal, but the occupation, and America’s profound misjudgment of its own power and limits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: U.S. Open Tightens Protocols, Fans Must Provide Proof of Covid Vaccination
description: Under pressure from the New York City mayor’s office, the U.S.T.A. reversed its rules for fans attending the tournament, which will have full capacity.
content: Under pressure from Mayor Bill de Blasio and other city leaders, the United States Tennis Association reversed its lax coronavirus protocols for the upcoming U.S. Open tournament, which opens to thousands of fans on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Powell
title: New York’s Private Schools Tackle White Privilege. It Has Not Been Easy.
description: In this world — where tuition runs as high as $58,000 — the topic has become flammable. Parents, faculty, students and alumni have all entered the fray.
content: Several years back Grace Church School, an elite private school in Manhattan, embraced an antiracist mission and sought to have students and teachers wrestle with whiteness, racial privilege and bias.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Music to Play NYT Games By
description: Listen to our Spotify playlist while you solve and suggest songs to add to it.
content: Games and music soothe the savage solver, so we’ve curated a playlist that you can listen to while you solve. All of the songs have something to do with our Crossword, Spelling Bee, Vertex, Tiles or Letter Boxed games, and we will be updating the list from time to time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: A deadly bombing in Kabul.
content: Dozens of people, including at least 13 U.S. troops, were killed in attacks by two suicide bombers in the crowds outside Afghanistan’s main airport yesterday, hours after Western governments had warned of an imminent Islamic State attack. Estimates of the toll range from at least 30 to more than 60. Follow live updates here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Hastreiter
title: Mel Ottenberg Takes Over Interview Magazine as Top Editor
description: The fashion stylist talks about superficiality, Instagram résumés, celebrity and carrying on the infamous Warhol legacy.
content: The fashion stylist Mel Ottenberg, 45, has dressed some of the world’s most influential celebrities (Rihanna and Justin Bieber) and worked with the biggest brands (Dior, Nike and Calvin Klein).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Schreiber
title: In Retiring Koosman’s Number, the Mets Protect Their History
description: A permanent tribute to Jerry Koosman, the left-hander who helped lead the team to World Series glory, is a move in the right direction for a club that tends to step on its own feet.
content: Back in late June, I went to a Mets-Phillies doubleheader at Citi Field and by the second inning of the first game I started to find myself assuming the worst.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Ronaldo’s Return to Manchester United Is Nostalgic Pragmatism
description: After flirting with joining Manchester City, Cristiano Ronaldo will instead head back to the team where he became a star. The reality is, almost no other club could afford him.
content: Massimiliano Allegri, given the circumstances, was surprisingly phlegmatic. His team’s first home game of the season was just a couple of days away, and the Juventus coach had just been told that the player around whom his club had painstakingly constructed its modern identity was no longer available for selection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: How Canadian Leaders Campaign in a Pandemic
description: While the Conservative leader Erin O’Toole is still hitting the road, his party has also created a virtual method of reaching voters.
content: After nearly two weeks of campaigning, it would be a stretch to say that election fever is sweeping Canada. Lawn signs are relatively scarce in Eastern Ontario, where I live, and others tell me similar stories from other parts of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Ida is expected to gain strength as it churns toward Louisiana.
description: The storm could become a major hurricane as it draws power from the warm waters of the Gulf of Mexico.
content: After “wobbling around,” as the National Hurricane Center put it late Thursday, Ida on Friday resumed a more stable track heading northwest, in effect guided by a ridge of high-pressure air off the Southeastern United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Hymes
title: How Do You Write Down a Scratching, Crunching Violin ‘Chop’?
description: The chop turns string players into beatboxers. After it developed organically over decades, musicians are making new efforts to notate it.
content: Change is hard. All the more so for an old, set-in-its-ways instrument like the violin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Intelligence Review Yields No Firm Conclusion on Origins of Coronavirus
description: Declassified portions of a report presented to President Biden revealed divisions among federal agencies over whether the virus came from a lab leak or emerged more naturally.
content: WASHINGTON — American intelligence agencies have not been able to determine if the coronavirus pandemic was the result of an accidental leak from a lab or if it emerged more naturally, according to declassified portions of a report to the White House that were released on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: The ‘Hedonistic Altruism’ of Plant-Based Meat
description: Ethan Brown, the founder and C.E.O. of Beyond Meat, on his moral and environmental priorities.
content: Ethan Brown contends there are several main benefits to consuming plant-based foods instead of animal meat. It leads to fewer greenhouse gas emissions, it consumes fewer natural resources and it is better for human health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: Making a Bid For Love
description: Brooke Hall and Albert Gladden met while vying for the same item at a charity auction. Their competition kicked off a friendship that blossomed into romance.
content: In April 2010, Albert Rupert Gladden was hoping that luck was on his side. He was at a fund-raising event for New York Needs You, now named America Needs You, an organization that promotes college completion for first-generation students. The fund-raiser included a silent auction, where attendees could bid on lunches with various executives in financial services. Mr. Gladden, who is now a regional director of institutional liquidity product management at Deutsche Bank in New York, was excited about the prospect of winning an item that aligned with his interests. There was one problem though. Every time he went to check on the auction he kept seeing the same name outbid him — Brooke Chanel Hall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Biden Vows ‘Unshakable Partnership’ With Israel in Meeting With Bennett
description: On Iran, a subject on which the two sharply disagree, President Biden said the United States was planning to put “diplomacy first” but “ready to turn to other options” if that fails.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Friday used his first meeting with Prime Minister Naftali Bennett of Israel to underscore that working closely with a longstanding ally in the Middle East was still a focus of his administration, even as the crisis in Afghanistan has opened him up to criticism that he is ceding ground in the wider region to extremists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Half of the adolescents in the U.S. have received at least one dose of a coronavirus vaccine, White House says.
description: Jeff Zients, the Covid-19 response coordinator, called the news “a major milestone in our efforts to vaccinate adolescents.”
content: Half of the 12- to 17-year-olds in the United States have gotten at least one dose of a coronavirus vaccine, the White House’s Covid-19 response coordinator, Jeff Zients, announced on Friday, a promising development in a group that has been hit harder by the Delta variant than earlier forms of the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Aug. 27, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Friday, Aug. 27, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Revealing His Identity, Capitol Police Officer Defends Shooting Rioter on Jan. 6
description: “I know that day I saved countless lives,” Lt. Michael Byrd said in an interview with NBC. He said shooting Ashli Babbitt, who smashed through a door near lawmakers, was a “last resort.”
content: Lt. Michael Byrd, the Capitol Police officer who fatally shot a rioter during the Jan. 6 attack, defended his actions in a televised interview on Thursday, saying that pulling the trigger had been a “last resort” that had prevented the mob from killing lawmakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: JoJo Siwa to Have First Same-Sex ‘Dancing With the Stars’ Partner
description: The “Dance Moms” alum and TikTok personality will join the ABC show as the first contestant to compete in a same-sex pairing.
content: On Thursday, “Dancing With the Stars” history was made with the announcement that the dancer and social media personality JoJo Siwa would be the first contestant on the ABC program to compete with a same-sex partner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Flo Rida, LL Cool J and Star Jones at the Angel Ball in the Hamptons
description: Despite the Delta surge, the charity circuit still draws celebrities, socialites and philanthropists.
content: “I’m assuming you’re vaccinated,” said Star Jones, the television personality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marty Mulvihill, Gretta Goldenman and Arlene Blum
title: Don’t Let the Fossil Fuel Industry Pivot to Toxic Plastics and Chemicals
description: As we confront climate change, focusing on a single metric, like greenhouse gas emissions, could leave other harmful practices unaddressed.
content: As the United States comes to grips with the climate crisis, fossil fuels will slowly recede from being primary sources of energy. That’s the good news. But the bad news is that the petrochemical industry is counting on greatly increasing the production of plastics and toxic chemicals made from fossil fuels to profit from its reserves of oil and gas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Jones
title: ‘Together’ Bears Witness to Britain’s Lockdowns
description: The new film, starring Sharon Horgan and James McAvoy, is a tensely funny relationship drama, as well as a chronicle of the first year of the pandemic.
content: LONDON — In “Together,” Sharon Horgan and James McAvoy play a couple in meltdown. And then the pandemic begins.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Robert Wright
description: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Robert Wright. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Robert Wright. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: How ‘Candyman’ Star Yahya Abdul-Mateen II Became the Next Big Name
description: The actor’s career has surged thanks to projects like “Aquaman” and “Watchmen.” He’s even become a Warner Bros. favorite. Now on the brink of movie stardom, he’s ready to steer.
content: “What time is it?” Yahya Abdul-Mateen II wondered. “I don’t know. I’ve been in this room …” He trailed off. “It could be any time of day right now.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleni Schirmer
title: We’re Burying Our Kids in Debt (Just Not the Way You Think)
description: Debt-financing public education has not only failed to provide schools with sufficient funds. It has also imposed long-term costs.
content: For the Philadelphia teacher Freda Anderson, setting up her classroom involves clearing plaster, dust and paint chips from tables, chairs and desks. Somewhere, a leak has allowed water to seep through the walls. Years of deferred maintenance have caused dust and paint chips to scatter across the room. This debris is not just a brazen reminder of state abandonment of public education — it is an active vector of harm. A report released this spring revealed an asbestos epidemic creeping through Philadelphia schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: ‘Tune in to Dan’: Californians uprooted by the Dixie fire find a link to home online.
description: Dan Kearns, a volunteer firefighter, streams live daily videos that bring up-to-the-minute information to a Northern California community scattered by evacuations and struggling with loss.
content: TAYLORSVILLE, Calif. — In the six long weeks since the Dixie fire, the second-largest blaze on record in California, erupted in the northern Sierra Nevada, the fire has scorched vast tracts of forest, incinerated gold-rush towns, and upended thousands of lives, forcing people across 1,000 square miles to flee their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: A Nightmare of Blood and Steel: The ’90s Subway Crash That Changed Everything
description: When a train jumped the tracks near Union Square, killing five and injuring 200, officials were forced to tighten safety protocols.
content: Thirty years ago this weekend, a speeding No. 4 train careened off the tracks near Union Square, leaving five people dead, 200 injured and a mess of crumpled and torn steel that shut down service for nearly a week. The train operator, who was later found to have excessive levels of alcohol in his blood, was charged with second-degree murder and was convicted of second-degree manslaughter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Madeleine Ngo
title: Powell Signals Federal Reserve Could Slow Bond Purchases This Year
description: The Fed chair warned that the Delta variant remained a risk and suggested that a rate increase was not on the table for some time.
content: Eighteen months into the pandemic, Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, has offered the strongest sign yet that the Fed is prepared to soon withdraw one leg of the support it has been providing to the economy as conditions strengthen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Clare Toeniskoetter, Annie Brown, Stella Tan, Neena Pathak, Larissa Anderson, Lisa Chow, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: The Bombings at the Kabul Airport
description: For days, the United States warned of the possibility of terrorist attacks as evacuations continued. Yesterday, it happened.
content: For days, many dreaded an attack on Hamid Karzai International Airport in Kabul, as Western forces scrambled to evacuate tens of thousands of people from Afghanistan. On Thursday, those fears were realized — amid the large crowds outside the airport, terrorists carried out two suicide bombings. The attacks killed at least 60 people, including 13 United States service members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Shaw
title: When Your Wedding Day Is Sept. 11
description: Getting married during a pandemic can force tough choices — including the date.
content: One evening in March 2020, Angeline Disante, 29, was tasting teriyaki steak on a stick to be served at her wedding on April 15. Once the pandemic hit, Ms. Disante and her fiancé rescheduled the wedding for Nov. 28. Not surprisingly, that one had to be postponed as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport, Sophie Kasakove and Conor Dougherty
title: Supreme Court’s Decision Opens Door to Millions of Evictions
description: The ruling late Thursday ending a new moratorium leaves the White House with few options to help renters at risk of losing their homes.
content: WASHINGTON — Millions of Americans around the country face the prospect of losing their homes after the Supreme Court on Thursday rejected the Biden administration’s latest federal moratorium on evictions, a decision that poses a new and unwelcome problem for a White House already grappling with domestic and international challenges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘This Is Broadway’ Campaign Aims to Attract Wary Theatergoers
description: The trade association representing theater owners and producers gets an assist from Oprah Winfrey as it seeks to drive ticket sales beyond the buzzy September reopenings.
content: Broadway producers and theater owners, concerned about whether fans are ready to return as dozens of shows prepare to start or resume performances, have banded together for an industrywide marketing campaign aimed at persuading Broadway’s core audience to purchase tickets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Gaia Pianigiani
title: Italian Official Resigns After Uproar Over Honoring Mussolini’s Brother
description: Claudio Durigon, a member of the right-wing League party and a deputy economy minister, had proposed to rename a park after Benito Mussolini’s brother.
content: ROME — An Italian government official resigned on Thursday after coming under fierce criticism for his proposal to rename a park in his hometown after the fascist brother of Italy’s former dictator, Benito Mussolini.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: Biden Floats Faster Access to Booster Shots Amid Spread of Variant
description: The White House played down the president’s remarks, saying the administration had not changed its original proposal to administer a third shot to most vaccinated adults eight months after the second.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden suggested on Friday that the government could offer coronavirus vaccine booster shots to most vaccinated adults sooner than eight months after a second shot, underscoring the administration’s concerns about the spread of the Delta variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba and Sheera Frenkel
title: Calls Grow to Discipline Doctors Spreading Virus Misinformation
description: A tiny number of doctors have had an outsize influence in spreading false information about Covid-19 and vaccines.
content: Standing before a local school board in central Indiana this month, Dr. Daniel Stock, a physician in the state, issued a litany of false claims about the coronavirus. He proclaimed that the recent surge in cases showed that the vaccines were ineffective, that people were better off with a cocktail of drugs and supplements to prevent hospitalization from the virus, and that masks didn’t help prevent the spread of infection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor, Zia ur-Rehman, Jim Huylebroek, Najim Rahim, Megan Specia, Fahim Abed and Helene Cooper
title: After one of the deadliest attacks in 20 years of war, many people are still trying to reach the airport.
description: The reported toll of the bombing outside Kabul’s airport rose sharply on Friday, with local health officials saying that as many as 170 people were killed and at least 200 were wounded. Yet less than a day after the attack, crowds on Friday sought once again to reach the airport, their desperation to flee the Taliban blending with grief at the enormous scale of the violence.
content: The reported toll of the bombing outside Kabul’s airport rose sharply on Friday, with local health officials saying that as many as 170 people were killed and at least 200 were wounded. Yet less than a day after the attack, crowds on Friday sought once again to reach the airport, their desperation to flee the Taliban blending with grief at the enormous scale of the violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis and Alex Marshall
title: Giant Puppet Ruffles Some Feathers on a Long Walk Through Greece
description: “Little Amal” is on a 5,000-mile journey from Turkey to Britain to highlight the plight of Syrian refugees. But in Greece, some have objected to her presence, saying it could encourage more migrants.
content: ATHENS — A giant puppet of a nine-year-old Syrian girl named Amal has been traveling across Turkey and Greece for much of the past month. It is the first leg of a 5,000-mile journey, one that is rich in symbolism as a new migration crisis looms in Europe following the Taliban takeover in Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: The Delta variant carries a higher risk of hospitalization, a study finds.
description: The analysis of more than 40,000 coronavirus infections in England adds to evidence suggesting that Delta may cause more severe illness than other variants do.
content: People who are infected with the highly contagious Delta variant are twice as likely to be hospitalized as those who are infected with the Alpha variant, according to a large new British study.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Florida court rejects effort by Gov. Ron DeSantis to ban mask mandates.
description: The governor’s legal team had previously indicated it will appeal the ruling to a more conservative appellate court.
content: A Florida court on Friday rejected an effort by Gov. Ron DeSantis and other state officials to prevent mask mandates in schools during the state’s worst Covid-19 outbreak yet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: Stream These Five International Films Now
description: This month’s picks include a rousing boxing film from India, a Costa Rican psychodrama, a breezy French romantic comedy, a horror film about refugees in London and a charming Tunisian indie.
content: In the age of streaming, the earth is flat — screen-size, with travel to faraway destinations only a monthly subscription and a click away. We’ve journeyed through the world of options and chosen the best new international movies for you to watch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Krauss
title: Finding Your Own Way With Words, and Images
description: 8 new picture books explore the many different paths to fall learning.
content: A KID IS A KID IS A KIDWritten by Sara O’LearyIllustrated by Qin Leng
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: Show Me the Data!
description: A lack of systematic evidence has kept scientists one step behind in the pandemic.
content: Who should get vaccine booster shots and when? Can vaccinated people with a breakthrough infection transmit the virus as easily as unvaccinated people? How many people with breakthrough infections die or get seriously ill, broken down by age and underlying health conditions?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: Satellites Spot Oceans Aglow With Trillions of Organisms
description: A new generation of detectors let scientists identify a dozen large episodes of bioluminescence, one a hundred times larger than Manhattan — and that’s the smallest.
content: The ocean has always glowed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Grant
title: Why My Daughter Got (Temporarily) Married at 13
description: Having been shamed about my sexuality when I was young, I was determined, as a mother, to celebrate my child’s romantic wishes.
content: Five years ago, when my daughter was in the 8th grade, she fell for a boy with strict, religious parents. Tall and slender with luxurious hair that swooped stylishly across his delicate face, he resembled a shy, well-mannered Justin Bieber. They both played soccer for their middle-school teams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: The White House projects that inflation and economic growth will rise this year.
description: The Biden administration revised its earlier forecasts to match the continued stimulus-fueled recovery from the recession.
content: The Biden administration on Friday said it expected economic growth and inflation to both reach their highest levels this year since the early 1980s, revising earlier forecasts to match the reality of the continued stimulus-fueled recovery from the recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Jordan
title: When the Book Review Went Really Harsh
description: A hundred years ago, headlines in the Book Review did not mince words.
content: From its very first issue in October 1896, the Book Review liked to deliver blunt edicts — and, as you’ll see, even blunter headlines. An 1898 review of George Bernard Shaw’s collected plays asserted that “he has not a touch of the poetical in his composition, and the critic and satirist who is not a bit of a poet cannot reasonably hope to win wide renown as a dramatist.” In 1907, Theodore Dreiser’s “Sister Carrie” was dismissed as “a book one can very well get along without reading,” and in 1908, L.M. Montgomery’s “Anne of Green Gables” was panned because the main character “greatly marred a story that had in it quaint and charming possibilities.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Greenway
title: He Built a Robot to Prove a Point About Refugees
description: As Afghans flee the Taliban, the experiences of a fellow countryman, Saidullah Karimi, warn of tough times ahead, but also carry a message of hope.
content: When Saidullah Karimi walks into the room, Athena’s blue eyes light up. When Mr. Karimi straightens his arm, Athena does, too. When he makes a fist, then uncurls his fingers, Athena does the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Watch a Scary Story Come to Life in ‘Candyman’
description: The director Nia DaCosta narrates a sequence that digs into the origins of the “Candyman” narrative using shadow puppetry.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Inflation rose again in July, the Fed’s preferred measure of prices shows.
description: The Personal Consumption Expenditures price index, based on household spending on goods and service, climbed 4.2 percent from a year ago, and 0.4 percent from June.
content: Inflation in the United States rose sharply again in July, the Federal Reserve’s preferred measure of prices showed, a pandemic-related jump that’s expected to fade but will keep pressure on policymakers until it does.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abrahm Lustgarten
title: 40 Million People Rely on the Colorado River. It’s Drying Up Fast.
description: Low water levels have triggered cutbacks to some Western states.
content: On a 110-degree day several years ago, surrounded by piles of sand and rock in the desert outside of Las Vegas, I stepped into a yellow cage large enough to fit three standing adults, and was lowered 600 feet through a black hole into the ground. There, at the bottom, amid pooling water and dripping rock, was an enormous machine driving a cone-shaped drill bit into the earth. The machine was carving a cavernous, three-mile tunnel beneath the bottom of the nation’s largest fresh water reservoir, Lake Mead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: William G. Clotworthy, ‘Saturday Night Live’ Censor, Dies at 95
description: A self-described “professional square,” he fell in love with the show, and worked with its writers to tweak questionable material. Cast members called him “Dr. No.”
content: William G. Clotworthy, who as the in-house censor for “Saturday Night Live” from 1979 to 1990 decided whether Eddie Murphy could say “bastard,” whether Joe Piscopo could make fart jokes and whether inebriated Romans could vomit on network television, died on Aug. 19 in Salt Lake City. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Where’s Eric Adams? Meeting Donors, From the Hamptons to the Vineyard.
description: Mr. Adams, the Democratic nominee for mayor of New York City, is rushing to raise $5 million for the general election in November.
content: On Martha’s Vineyard last weekend, as most residents braced for the possible arrival of Hurricane Henri, a smaller gathering focused on a more certain visitor: Eric Adams, New York City’s likely next mayor.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Vaccines Are Top Defense, but Virus Can Still Slip By
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, August 27, 2021.
content: “The unvaccinated are a big highway of transmission. The vaccinated are a little side street.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Right-Wingers Who Admire the Taliban
description: For some reactionaries, a victory over "liberalism" is something to gloat about.
content: As the Taliban swept through Afghanistan in August, a Gen Z alt-right group ran a Twitter account devoted to celebrating their progress. Tweets in Pashto juxtaposed two laughing Taliban fighters with pictures meant to represent American effeminacy. Another said, the words auto-translated into English, “Liberalism did not fail in Afghanistan because it was Afghanistan, it failed because it was not true. It failed America, Europe and the world see it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Why Is It Taking So Long to Get a Covid Vaccine for Kids?
description: Parents hoping for an early-fall vaccine may have to wait until the end of the year to get children under 12 vaccinated.
content: This is a preview of the Well newsletter, which is reserved for Times subscribers. Sign up to get it in your inbox weekly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Apple Avoids Another Legal Fight With App Developers
description: It also will create a $100 million fund to pay them. A judge’s decision in a higher-profile fight with Epic Games, a leading video game maker, is still pending.
content: Apple, in a legal settlement announced on Thursday with a group of app developers, said it would allow developers to urge customers to pay them outside their iPhone apps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Marx
title: Better Apart, Then Together Again
description: Despite a 15-year age gap and a decade of ups and downs, Jennifer Chu and Charonton Barber found the confidence and patience to embrace their differences.
content: It was an awkward first encounter. In March, 2011, when Jennifer Chu was 19 and the single mother of three-year-old daughter Orianna, she was introduced to Charonton Barber, a 2002 U.S. Naval Academy graduate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: How to Make Your Marriage More Financially Equal
description: Whether you’re newlyweds or not, your marriage can only benefit from a better balance that eases the stress on both of you. But be ready to talk — “we” statements only, please.
content: A year and a half of pandemic living has revealed — or reminded us of — some persistent patterns around money, gender, marriage and families. And they aren’t always pretty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: Louis XIV Brought Them Together in Paris
description: Nathalie Demirdjian had on her “French face” when she met Justin Rivest at an academic conference on the French royal court. He was just being his Canadian self.
content: It was October 2017 and they were in Paris for a two-day history-of-medicine colloquium on the subject of the French royal court. As she handed him his name tag, the first thing that Nathalie Demirdjian noticed about Justin Rivest was that he was all smiles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derek M. Norman
title: Some Hotels Are Mandating Vaccines. Will Others Follow?
description: Following the lead of accommodations abroad, some U.S. hotels are starting to require proof of vaccination for guests and staff.
content: As travelers prepare for their next vacation, among the essentials to take along — like a toothbrush, wallet and phone charger — could be proof of vaccination for Covid-19, depending on where they are booked to sleep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Run From Here to There
description: Robyn Weintraub opens our solving weekend in style.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Hot diggety, it’s a Weintraub! (In my head I said something different, but this is at least standards friendly.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Emma Corrin Is Fine With Not Playing Diana to the Bitter End
description: The British actor, who received an Emmy nomination for playing Diana in “The Crown,” is happy to be handing off the role as it takes a darker turn. “I feel very protective over her,” she said.
content: Voting is underway for the 73rd Primetime Emmys, and this week we’re talking to several first-time Emmy nominees. The awards will be presented Sept. 19 on CBS.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi, Noam Scheiber and Lauren Hirsch
title: Rivian, Electric Truck Maker Backed by Amazon and Ford, Files for I.P.O.
description: Auto analysts consider Rivian one of the most viable electric vehicle start-ups in what is expected to be a very competitive market.
content: Rivian, a promising and well-funded electric truck maker, plans to sell shares through an initial public offering, the company said Friday, just weeks before it expects to deliver its first electric pickups to customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Difrancesco
title: Stories Spanning Countries and Generations, by Jo Lloyd, Yoon Choi and Hilma Wolitzer
description: New fiction about Korean immigrants in America, 1960s New York housewives and aging butterfly collectors exploring the world one last time.
content: SOMETHING WONDERFUL Stories By Jo Lloyd 219 pp. Tin House. $24.95.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Jerome Powell speaks at the Fed’s closely watched annual conference.
description: Instead of laying out how the Fed will taper its bond-buying, Mr. Powell instead explained how the Fed was thinking about Delta variant risks and recent rapid inflation.
content: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, spoke on Friday at an annual conference hosted by the Kansas City Fed, signaling that the central bank could begin to withdraw some support for the economy this year as the job market heals from the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: Apple’s Shrewd App Store Settlement
description: The agreement to allow developers to promote payment options outside the App Store may give Apple the upper hand in bigger fights to come.
content: When Apple settled a lawsuit yesterday brought by a group of small app developers, it represented a shift in the balance of power in an app ecosystem that the tech giant has long tightly controlled. Just how much of a shift is up for debate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Van Syckle
title: In Climate Coverage, Reporting the Grim Facts, but Also the Fight
description: A Times journalist distills the recent U.N. report and talks about how he treats a beat that can get more than a little gloomy.
content: The United Nations recently released a major scientific report concluding that a hotter future is certain but that there is still a chance to prevent the most dire outcomes. Brad Plumer, a climate reporter for The New York Times, says there is a consensus among scientists on what must happen to limit global warming: Nations need to stop adding greenhouse gases to the atmosphere. In an interview, Mr. Plumer, who focuses on the policy and technology efforts to cut carbon dioxide emissions, discussed the significance of the U.N. report, how he approaches a subject that can be upsetting to readers and his own environmentally conscious efforts. This interview has been edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti, Julian E. Barnes and Adam Goldman
title: Amid Afghan Chaos, a C.I.A. Mission That Will Persist for Years
description: The spy agency had plans to de-emphasize counterterrorism operations to focus on rising global powers. History got in the way.
content: WASHINGTON — As the Afghanistan war wound down, the C.I.A. had expected to gradually shift its primary focus away from counterterrorism — a mission that transformed the agency over two decades into a paramilitary organization focused on manhunts and killing — toward traditional spycraft against powers like China and Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: India hits a vaccination milestone, giving at least one shot to more than half of its eligible population.
description: The country has given at least one Covid-19 vaccine shot to more than half of the eligible population.
content: India has given at least one Covid-19 vaccine shot to more than half of the eligible population, a milestone in a country that initially struggled to roll out enough doses for its 1.4 billion people.
source.name: The New York Times

title: William Maxwell Found the Depth in Modest Places
description: A.O. Scott talks about the novelist and story writer, and Eyal Press discusses “Dirty Work.”
content: A.O. Scott, The Times’s co-chief film critic, returns to the Book Review’s podcast this week to discuss the work of William Maxwell, the latest subject in Scott’s essay series The Americans, about writers who give a sense of the country’s complex identity. In his novels and stories, Maxwell frequently returned to small-town Illinois, and to, as Scott describes it, the “particular civilization and culture and society that he knew growing up.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Donald Newlove, 93, Dies; Novelist Explored the Depths of Drink
description: His acclaimed fiction and a memoir had a common theme: alcoholism. After becoming sober, he called his former besotted muse “Drunkspeare.”
content: Donald Newlove, a recovered alcoholic who wrote acclaimed, brutally unsentimental novels and a memoir with a common theme — drunkenness — as well as cheeky primers on reading and writing, died on Aug. 17 in Bethesda, Md. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Orr
title: ‘Ted Lasso’ Recap, Season 2, Episode 6: The Roy Kent Effect
description: Is Ted OK? Is Nate? And who is Rebecca’s secret admirer?
content: So, does this mean we’re back to normal?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland and Erin Schaff
title: At a Children’s Hospital, a Wave of Young Patients Struggling to Breathe
description: A federal “surge team” is helping exhausted doctors and nurses through one of the most trying periods in the history of Children’s Hospital New Orleans.
content: NEW ORLEANS — Helpless to improve her infant son’s breathing as he was about to be intubated, Catherine Perrilloux did the only thing that came naturally to her in that moment, the worst of her life: She looked away and prayed. The boy, known as Junior, was two months old and gravely ill with Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Reid J. Epstein
title: Texas House Passes Voting Bill as G.O.P. Nears a Hard-Fought Victory
description: The Republican bill, which would overhaul elections in Texas and introduce a range of new voting rules, must be approved by the State Senate before it can head to Gov. Greg Abbott’s desk.
content: AUSTIN — The Texas House of Representatives passed a sweeping election overhaul bill on Friday, clearing a major hurdle in a monthslong push by Republicans to introduce a host of new voting rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong and Li Yuan
title: The Rise and Fall of the World’s Ride-Hailing Giant
description: Didi pushed the limits and thrived in legal gray areas. Until China cracked down.
content: China’s leading ride-hailing company, Didi, was an operation of dubious legality when it raised its first big bucket of money nearly a decade ago. And in one way or another, it has been testing the authorities ever since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Vacation Friends’ Review: Life Lessons Amid Chaos
description: Clay Tarver’s movie is a better grade of outrageous couples comedy.
content: The outrageous couples comedy is by now an established if not reliable genre. “Vacation Friends” has a quality advantage in the casting of the couples; Lil Rel Howery, Yvonne Orji, John Cena and Meredith Hagner are all guaranteed laugh generators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: A Crunchy Late-Summer Salad
description: Cook with the freshest produce — while you still can.
content: I’m off next week — my wonderful colleague Margaux Laskey will be writing to you instead — and as I chose recipes for you below, I realized that this was my last newsletter of the summer, and that there are so many more recipes I wanted to share before it’s over. (Yes, summer technically ends in late September, but emotionally it ends on Labor Day.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Reggie Ugwu
title: Spike Lee Removes Conspiracists From HBO 9/11 Series After Criticism
description: The filmmaker edited his documentary after critics said it provided a platform for discredited theories purporting that the towers had been secretly blown up.
content: Quickly responding to criticism that an episode of his HBO documentary series on the Sept. 11 attacks gave credence to conspiracy theories, the filmmaker Spike Lee on Thursday released to the media a new final cut that removes all interviews about what caused the World Trade Center buildings to collapse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Apps Try Putting Financial Literacy at Kids’ Fingertips
description: They can be valuable resources to help parents teach children about money — but may encourage risky behaviors, some experts say.
content: A new crop of mobile money apps are promoting themselves as part of the solution to a stubborn problem: a lack of financial savvy, particularly among young Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Love Letter: A Temporary Teen Marriage
description: And: a fusion farm wedding.
content: Many people vow to avoid their parents’ mistakes when raising their own children. For Stephanie Grant, a professor and the author of this week’s Modern Love essay, that meant permitting her 13-year-old daughter to enter into a temporary marriage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Retro Icebox Pie Gets a Vibrant Makeover
description: Add some refrigerator alchemy to vanilla wafers, fresh strawberries and mounds of whipped cream for a dreamy, creamy late-summer dessert.
content: There are few two-ingredient desserts as transcendent as an icebox cake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Messi, Mbappé and Running Out the Clock
description: Lionel Messi moved to P.S.G. because Barcelona couldn’t stop him. Kylian Mbappé may have to stay put because his club holds all the leverage.
content: Real Madrid’s first offer for Kylian Mbappé arrived, in writing, on Tuesday afternoon. It did not come as a shock to anyone at Paris St.-Germain, not really. Mbappé had only a year left on his contract. Negotiations over an extension had long ago hit an impasse. It was an open secret he had eyes only for Real Madrid. Clumsily, the Spanish club had made clear it reciprocated his affection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Austin Police Officer Is Charged With Murder in a Second On-Duty Killing
description: Prosecutors said Friday that Christopher Taylor had been charged with fatally shooting Mauris DeSilva in July 2019, about nine months before he fatally shot another man.
content: A police officer in Austin, Texas, who was charged with murdering a man in April 2020 has been charged with murdering another man about nine months earlier, prosecutors said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Why Would an Economist Ever Look on the Bright Side?
description: For Wall Street, and the dismal science as a whole, trouble is around every corner even as the economy booms.
content: America’s dismal scientists can paint even a blue-sky outlook gray.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: What Happened to This Hero From the American Revolution?
description: The Marquis de Lafayette had quite a second act.
content: On June 13, 1777, Marie-Joseph Paul Yves Roch Gilbert du Motier — the Marquis de Lafayette — arrived on American soil. He had come for glory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy and Dave Philipps
title: He was a baby on 9/11. Now he’s one of the last casualties of America’s longest war.
description: Rylee McCollum, barely older than the war itself, had a wife and a baby on the way. He was one of the first publicly identified American victims of the suicide bombing at Kabul’s airport.
content: After Lance Cpl. Rylee McCollum, 20, landed in Afghanistan with his Marine unit, his father, Jim, began checking his phone for a little green dot. Mr. McCollum had not been able to talk with his son, but the green dot next to Rylee’s name on a messaging app meant that he was online. That he was still OK.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: How to Enjoy Retirement Without Going Broke
description: The problem of decumulation is a tricky one, even for Nobel Prize-winning economists.
content: I’ve been asking readers to suggest ideas, and I got this one last week from Jerry Moskowitz of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.: “I teach a class for seniors called Keeping Current in Economics and Finance. An interesting subject may be decumulation — how to successfully spend money in retirement.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter and Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Launches Strike on ISIS-K as Bombing’s Death Toll Soars
description: The Pentagon said its drone strike appeared to have killed a planner for the terror group, which claimed responsibility for the blast at Kabul’s airport that left more than 170 dead.
content: The U.S. military said on Friday night that it had launched its first reprisal strike for the devastating suicide bombing at Kabul’s airport the day before, using a drone to target and apparently kill a planner for the group that claimed responsibility for the deaths of as many as 170 civilians and 13 U.S. service members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: New Zealand’s Homegrown Hero
description: Can the celebrity civil servant steering New Zealand through its lockdown succeed again?
content: Last October, I attended a rock concert by Don McGlashan, a veteran New Zealand singer-songwriter, in Wellington. Halfway through, he paused the show to call for a round of applause for someone in the audience: Ashley Bloomfield, the country’s top health official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: What Is the Islamic State Khorasan, a.k.a. ISIS-K?
description: Founded in 2015, the Afghan branch of the Islamic State counts both U.S. forces and the Taliban as its foes.
content: Shortly after a bombing attack killed masses of people on Thursday, including at least 13 U.S. troops and more than 170 civilians outside Afghanistan’s main airport, President Biden vowed to get revenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Stephen B. Oates, Civil War Historian, Dies at 85
description: In a quartet of biographies, he explored how slavery and racial oppression could exist in a land based on the ideals of the Declaration of Independence.
content: Stephen B. Oates, a Civil War historian and the biographer of several prominent Americans, including Abraham Lincoln, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and William Faulkner, died on Aug. 20 at his home in Amherst, Mass. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cindy Shmerler
title: Overlooked No More: Randy Snow, Paralympic Champion of Wheelchair Tennis
description: He won gold medals in singles and doubles at the 1992 Games in Barcelona and was the first Paralympic athlete to be inducted into the Olympic Hall of Fame.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kira Thurman
title: When Europe Offered Black Composers an Ear
description: Spurned by institutions in America, artists were sometimes given more opportunities across the Atlantic.
content: In early September 1945, amid the rubble of a bombed-out Berlin, the Afro-Caribbean conductor Rudolph Dunbar stepped onto a podium and bowed to an enthusiastic audience of German citizens and American military personnel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Perlez
title: Pakistan emerges as a winner. What will it do now?
description: Just days after the Taliban took Kabul, their flag was flying high above a central mosque in Pakistan’s capital. It was an in-your-face gesture intended to spite the defeated Americans — and a sign of the real victors in the 20-year Afghan war.
content: Just days after the Taliban took Kabul, their flag was flying high above a central mosque in Pakistan’s capital. It was an in-your-face gesture intended to spite the defeated Americans — and a sign of the real victors in the 20-year Afghan war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: An uncertain return to school.
content: The third school year of the pandemic is upon us, and virtually no one is happy with where things stand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden faces a tragedy he worked to avoid.
description: President Biden’s decision to end America’s longest war was driven, he had said repeatedly, by his determination not to sacrifice even one more member of the military on behalf of an effort that he had long believed was no longer in the interests of the United States.
content: President Biden’s decision to end America’s longest war was driven, he had said repeatedly, by his determination not to sacrifice even one more member of the military on behalf of an effort that he had long believed was no longer in the interests of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Lloyd Dobyns, Co-Anchor of an Innovative TV Newscast, Dies at 85
description: He teamed with Linda Ellerbee on “NBC News Overnight” in 1982 to set an unusual tone for network news in an equally unusual time slot.
content: Lloyd Dobyns, an award-winning NBC News correspondent who in the early 1980s was the co-anchor of the innovative television newscast “NBC News Overnight,” died on Sunday in Mebane, N.C., northwest of Raleigh. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: A study confirms a small risk of blood clots after vaccines, but not as high as the risk Covid brings.
description: The study adds to the growing evidence that though the coronavirus vaccines are associated with certain rare side effects, those risks are dwarfed by the risks from Covid-19.
content: The largest published study to date of certain post-vaccine side effects found that people were at slightly higher than normal risk of blood clots after receiving an AstraZeneca or Pfizer-BioNTech shot. But the same clotting conditions were substantially more likely to occur — and over longer periods — among people infected with the coronavirus, the study found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: As Schools Reopen, Districts Are Desperate for Bus Drivers
description: School officials are getting creative, offering bonuses and other incentives to address a driver shortage that the pandemic made worse.
content: As schools return to in-person learning with masks and social distancing, some districts are facing another challenge: getting students to class.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Send Us a Video With Your Question About Kids and Covid
description: What would you like to ask our reporters?
content: When it comes to children and Covid, it can feel like there are more questions than answers. How will new variants affect them? How will they go back to school safely?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: Return of the Pied-à-terre
description: With much of New York City back in business, some of the people who left during the pandemic are coming back. Sort of.
content: When the coronavirus shut down New York City last year, Meredith Blair, a longtime resident of the Upper West Side, moved with her family to their weekend house in New Fairfield, Conn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: How Can I Make Shorts Chic?
description: A reader has finally found flattering shorts, but wants to avoid looking matronly when pairing them with a T-shirt or tank top.
content: Shorts are the summer equivalent of winter’s sweats, so I imagine that while back-to-the-office conversations hang in the air (given concerns about the highly contagious Delta variant of the coronavirus), how to adapt our current dress when that eventual return date arrives remains a pressing question for many.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: In Saratoga Springs, Horse Racing’s Troubles Cloud a Tradition
description: Will horse racing right itself so people can visit Saratoga Springs for another century or two?
content: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — The man who was once the most famous sportswriter in America is said to have uttered the most famous words about this town and racetrack. How do you get to Saratoga, Red Smith was asked?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: This Is How Theocracy Shrivels
description: Radical ideas that once made Islamist extremism seem galvanizing have lost their luster.
content: Certain years leap out as turning points in world history: 1517, 1776 and 1917. These are years when powerful ideas strode onto the world stage: the Reformation, democratic capitalism and revolutionary Communism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Jerry Harkness, 81, Dies; Star of a Historic Integrated Basketball Team
